test.input: CHEST: Devices: Right subclavian central line has tip at the superior cavoatrial junction. Enteric tubes x2 turbinate with tips in the stomach and proximal jejunum. Median sternotomy wires are intact and aligned. Mediastinal drains x2) appropriate position, with trace fluid surrounding the anterior mediastinal drain. Lymph nodes: No axillary, hilar, or mediastinal lymphadenopathy. Mediastinum: Post surgical changes are present including clips and mediastinal drains. Small but not rim-enhancing anterior fluid collection along the course of the mediastinal drain (e.g. image 208 series 5), as well as several small foci of air along the drain's course. Soft tissue/fluid density surrounds the ascending aorta and aortic arch as well as the major branch vessels (e.g. image 21 series 6), along with a slightly higher density ovoid 1.2 cm structure which may be a small clot (image 19 series 6). Great vessels: Patient is status post interval aortic arch repair, with patent origins of the 3 great arch vessels. No evidence of recurrent aortic aneurysm/pseudoaneurysm, dissection, or aortic rupture although there is a small tubular outpouching along the right aspect of the aortic arch (image 123 series 5) which is likely an expected postsurgical finding (per operative report: "The reperfusion branch and the extra branch of the aortic graft were ligated at their origin. [...] They may have the appearance of a pseudoaneurysm on a later CT scan, but these do not represent pseudoaneurysms."). Normal appearance of the pulmonary artery and its lobar branches. Heart: Symmetrically enlarged, without focal abnormality. No pericardial effusion. Lungs: Interval improvement in the previously seen pulmonary contusions, with some small residual there is a likely scarring (e.g. image 123 series 5 on the right). No visible posttraumatic pneumatoceles. There is dependent atelectasis, left greater than right, and a focal rounded nonspecific pulmonary opacity in the right supradiaphragmatic region appears smaller (image 323 series 5), possibly another resolving pulmonary contusion or improving pneumonia. Pleural spaces: There is a low to intermediate density right pleural effusion, without pleural enhancement. There is a loculated appearing tubular pathway along the right anterolateral pleural space, with predominantly soft tissue and some small locules of air density along it, which may represent scarring along the course of the prior pneumothorax, although there is no definite rim-enhancing fluid collection at this location to suggest abscess. There is no discrete right pneumothorax. There is a small slightly loculated left pleural effusion, without pleural enhancement. Musculoskeletal system and soft tissues: Healing median sternotomy. No other fractures within the thoracic spine or thoracic cage. ABDOMEN/PELVIS: Liver and biliary tree: No focal hepatic abnormality. Mild central hepatic biliary ductal dilatation. The CBD is difficult to differentiate from surrounding tissues. Gallbladder: Unremarkable. Spleen: Surgically absent. Pancreas:The body and tail are well-defined and homogeneously enhancing. Pancreatic duct stent has been placed since 10/10/2021. The pancreatic head/neck junction is hypoenhancing (e.g. image 282 series 3).. The uncinate process appears to enhance normally. Adrenal Glands: Right adrenal gland is unremarkable. A small amount of fluid is present along the superior aspect of left adrenal gland, possibly tracking from the pancreatic tail. Kidneys: There are kidney is unremarkable. The left kidney shows normal enhancement in its inferior pole and patchy enhancement in its mid to superior poles, consistent with known renal laceration and left superior renal artery disruption. No obstructive uropathy is seen on either side. Urinary Bladder: Contains Foley catheter, collapsed which limits evaluation. Pelvic Organs: Unremarkable. Bowel: No bowel obstruction. No focal bowel wall thickening or dilatation. Appendix is normal in appearance. Peritoneum/retroperitoneum: Small amount of free pelvic fluid, without peripheral enhancement (e.g. image 638 series 3). There is a rim-enhancing fluid collection in the left upper quadrant adjacent to the pancreatic tail which measures approximately 5.4 x 3.6 x 2.9 cm (image 26 series 3), with a left upper quadrant surgical drain coursing through it. A small amount of free fluid is seen coursing along the left paracolic gutter. Lymph Nodes: No abdominal or pelvic lymphadenopathy, with the caveat that indistinct soft tissue thickening is present along the pancreatic head/neck and is difficult to fully evaluate the porta hepatis region.. Vessels: Duplicated right renal arteries appear patent. The left lower renal artery seen on the prior examination appears patent; the truncated left upper renal artery present on 10/10/2021 is not visible today. Origins of the SMA and celiac trunk appear patent. Proximal IMA is patent. No abdominal aortic aneurysm. Musculoskeletal system and soft tissue: Apparent right gluteal hematoma with peripheral calcification extends along the surgical tract over the right hip; no definite rim enhancement is seen at this location. Partially visualized right femoral orthopedic hardware. No visualized fractures in the lumbar spine or pelvis.

test.input: Lungs/Airways/Pleura : Central tracheobronchial tree is patent. Scattered punctate (less than 1 mm) centrilobular micronodules. Stable 4 mm nodule at the left lung base (3:405). Mild bronchiectasis in the left lower lobe. Tree-in-bud nodules in the left lower lobe noted on prior exam have resolved. No new or enlarging nodules. No pleural effusion or pneumothorax. Mediastinum/Lymph nodes: No thoracic adenopathy. Visualized thyroid is unremarkable. Heart and Vessels: The heart appears normal in size. No pericardial effusion. Normal course and caliber of the aorta. Minimal aortic and coronary artery calcifications. Upper Abdomen: Unremarkable. Osseous structures and Soft Tissues: No aggressive bone lesions.
labels: Tiny growths in the lungs. Mild airway damage. Hardening of the aorta and heart's blood vessels.
